title: Switch statements
question: Which of these statements are true about switch case?
hint: Swift takes the safety of your code seriously, which means it will make sure all possibilities are handled.
correct: Switch statements are often clearer to read than multiple if conditions.
Code from the following case will be run if you use fallthrough
You must list all outcomes as case statements or use default.
You place the value you want to check at the start.
The default case is written as default: rather than case default:
If you want to match all other values, use default

wrong.answer: Switch statements don't work with integers.
wrong.reason: Switch statements work just fine with integers.

wrong.answer: The default case is always needed.
wrong.reason: This default case is not needed if you already cover all other cases, such as with an enum.
You can use fallthrough as many times as you want.

wrong.answer: Switch statements work best with constants.
wrong.reason: Switch statements work just fine with variables.

wrong.answer: You can have a maximum of 10 cases.
wrong.reason: You may have as many cases as you want.

wrong.answer: Switch statements make your code run more slowly.
